div1.p: Smith's report details the medical examination of a suspected case of yellow fever and concludes that it was not yellow fever.

div1.head: Report by Lucian C. Smith, August 28, 1923 [Enclosed in C0302036]
div1.p:
Notes on case held under observation for yellow fever by
Dr. W. L. Mabry, of the Huesteca Company, at San Jeronimo. The patient
was visited and examined by me in consultation with Dr. Mabry in a small
isolation ward, designated as the Pest House, in connection with the
camp hospital, about 10 o'clock the evening of August 27.

Name: Unknown. For the time the patient was carried on the
hospital records by number only. She appeared to have no relatives or
particular friends in the native village across the river from the oil
camp where she was discovered critically ill, and from which place she
was removed to the hospital at the direction of Dr. Mabry, the evening
of August 25.

Nativity: Native Mexican woman of Indian type, but place of
birth and previous residence undetermined. The Doctor was informed
that the woman had been living in the native village close to the camp
about three weeks, having come there from Cierra Azul, where she had
been living prior to that for two months.

Previous history: Very little definite information had been
obtained as to her previous history. Social condition, unmarried. She
was said to have had children and to have been living irregularly in the
native village. When Dr. Mabry first saw her she made some statement to
the effect that she had been beaten and kicked in the abdomen by some
man with whom she had been living in irregular relations. Later, the
doctor said, she denied that story. She told the nurse that she had
several attacks of abdominal pain with vomiting of blood in the past
three years. She gave an account of having had an attack of peritonites,
three months ago, that is, according to the symptoms she described. Dr.
Mabry first saw the woman in a cantina in the village the evening of the
24th.
No history of initial chill elicited.

Present Illness: When the case first came under the observation
of Dr. Mabry the woman had attracted the attention of neighbors on account
of vomiting blood. The history of the duration of the attack varied from
a few hours to several days. When the Doctor first saw her she was having
frequent paroxysms of vomiting. Some of the material ejected was dark red,
conforming to the type of “coffee-ground” vomitus. At intervals consider-
able quantities of bright red blood came up, apparently unmixed with gas-
tric secretions. Dr. Mabry thought that within 20 minutes she had dis-
gorged over a pint of bloody material. The hemorrhage at that time seemed
to threaten her life immediately. Temperature at 6 P.M. that day 99.8
Pulse 123. The principal complaint of the patient was of severe pain in
the epigastric region, located with maximum intensity in the “pit of the
stomach”; together with cramps in the calves and arms. The next evening
the patient was brought over to the Pest House and placed under a mosquito
bar with quarantine regulations. The temperature remained about the same.
- 2 -
Pulse rate 111. After being placed in the Pest House the vomiting
subsided. The patient had not complained of nausea or vomiting after
the evening of the 25th. The temperature was slightly lower, 99.2,
on Sunday morning (the 26th) Pulse rate 107. Continued to complain
of pain in the stomach and pain cramp in the thighs and arms. The
morning temperature Monday, the 27th, was normal. Pulse 103. Evening
temperature 38, pulse 113. The Doctor had been informed of the appear-
ance of blood in the stools early in her illness, but there was no blood
in the stools after she came under the observation of Dr. Mabry.

Physical Examination. General appearance: Fairly well nour-
ished and moderately well developed young woman of Indian type. She
did not look critically ill on inspection. However, when attempts were
made to question her she appeared mentally clouded, answering incoher-
ently or irrelevantly. When asked if she was suffering pain she in-
variably placed her hand over the epigastric region. On inspection under
electric flash light it was not possible to discover any ichteroid tinge.
Dr. Mabry said that her conjunctivae had been slightly yellow the first
and the second day she was under his observation. The tongue was broad,
unindented by teeth marks, covered with a slight, whitish coat. The tip
and edges were not marked red. There was no marked tremor observed upon
protrusion. The gums were not bleeding. No oosing was observed. To
the finger they did not feel spongy. Dr. Mabry said that the appearance
of the tongue had remained about the same.

The heart and lungs appeared negative. The abdomen was negative
to inspection. On palpation over the stomach pain was elicited by slight
pressure. The spleen could not be palpated by this examiner (L.C.Smith)
but Dr. Mabry said that the spleen had been palpable. At that time he
said he could feel the edge of the organ under his fingers on deep pal-
pation with the patient turned on the right side. The liver did not
appear definitely enlarged on physical examination. It appeared ample
within normal limits. Dr. Mabry was satisfied that he had detected ten-
derness and increased tensio in the region of the gall bladder. This was
not evident to this examiner. Dr. Mabry reported marked abdominal tym-
panitis, with slight distention, at first.Further physical examination
was generally negative.

The examination of the urine-August 27-showed a heavy trace of
albumen. Specific gravity 1033. Not reported for casts. Gross appear-
ance of urine decidedly high colored, “febrile” type. Scanty in quantity.
The treatment has been wholly symptomatic.

Conclusion: In the opinion of this examiner this is not a
case of yellow fever.
